query: Calabi-Yau compactification Standard Model string theory F-theory heterotic string flux compactification Hodge numbers vector bundle Large Volume Scenario Kreuzer-Skarke swampland conjecture

concepts.label: F theory
concepts.description: A non-perturbative formulation of type IIB string theory defined via compactification on elliptic fibrations, providing a geometric framework for understanding strong coupling physics.

concepts.label: heterotic string
concepts.description: A consistent superstring theory based on the heterotic gauge group E8 × E8 or SO(32), compactified on Calabi-Yau manifolds.

concepts.label: holomorphic G bundle
concepts.description: A principal bundle with structure group G over a complex manifold, equipped with a holomorphic connection compatible with the complex structure.

concepts.label: elliptic Calabi-Yau manifold
concepts.description: A Kähler manifold with trivial canonical bundle that admits an elliptic fibration structure, used in compactifications of string theories.

concepts.label: string duality
concepts.description: Equivalence between different string theory compactifications or formulations that describe the same physical theory at different coupling regimes.

concepts.label: string compactification
concepts.description: Geometric process of curling up extra spatial dimensions on a compact manifold to obtain a lower-dimensional effective string theory.

concepts.label: gauge group
concepts.description: The symmetry group whose elements parametrize gauge transformations and structure group of principal bundles in string theory.

concepts.label: elliptic fibration
concepts.description: A surjective holomorphic map from a manifold to a base space whose generic fiber is an elliptic curve.

concepts.label: Calabi-Yau threefold
concepts.description: A complex threefold with vanishing first Chern class and holonomy group SU(3), used to compactify extra dimensions in string theory.

concepts.label: Hodge numbers
concepts.description: Topological invariants h^{p,q} characterising the cohomology of a Calabi-Yau manifold.

concepts.label: holonomy group
concepts.description: The group of parallel transport transformations of tangent vectors around closed loops on a manifold.

concepts.label: SU(3)
concepts.description: The special unitary group of dimension 3; the precise holonomy group of a generic Calabi-Yau threefold.

concepts.label: height
concepts.description: A measure of the complexity or discriminant of a Calabi-Yau threefold, used to classify manifolds by smallness.

concepts.label: complete intersection Calabi-Yau
concepts.description: A Calabi-Yau threefold defined as the transverse intersection of hypersurfaces in projective space.

concepts.label: free quotient
concepts.description: A Calabi-Yau threefold obtained by taking a free action quotient of another Calabi-Yau threefold by a finite group.

concepts.label: Hodge plot
concepts.description: A graphical representation of Calabi-Yau threefolds plotted by their Hodge numbers h^{1,1} and h^{2,1}.

concepts.label: Type II string theory
concepts.description: A ten-dimensional superstring theory with two supersymmetries; includes type IIA and type IIB variants related by T-duality.

concepts.label: Four-dimensional compactification
concepts.description: A reduction of a higher-dimensional string theory to four spacetime dimensions by compactifying extra dimensions on a compact manifold.

concepts.label: Six-dimensional compactification
concepts.description: A reduction of a higher-dimensional string theory to six spacetime dimensions by compactifying extra dimensions, leaving a lower-dimensional effective theory.

concepts.label: Strong coupling transition
concepts.description: A non-perturbative phase transition or regime change in string theory that occurs when the coupling constant becomes large and perturbative methods fail.

concepts.label: Heterotic coupling constant
concepts.description: The dimensionless parameter controlling the strength of heterotic string interactions; at strong coupling, non-perturbative effects become important.

concepts.label: Geometric symmetry
concepts.description: A symmetry operation on the compactification geometry, such as automorphisms or modular transformations of the manifold underlying the string compactification.

concepts.label: Non-perturbative effects
concepts.description: Physical phenomena and corrections that cannot be computed using perturbation theory and arise at strong coupling, including instantons and branes.

concepts.label: heterotic string theory
concepts.description: Ten-dimensional string theory with left-moving supersymmetric and right-moving bosonic sectors, existing in three distinct gauge group formulations.

concepts.label: SO(16)×SO(16) theory
concepts.description: Non-supersymmetric ten-dimensional heterotic string theory with gauge group SO(16)×SO(16).

concepts.label: E8×E8 theory
concepts.description: Supersymmetric ten-dimensional heterotic string theory with gauge group E8×E8.

concepts.label: SO(32) theory
concepts.description: Supersymmetric ten-dimensional heterotic string theory with gauge group SO(32).

concepts.label: Calabi-Yau compactification
concepts.description: Geometric compactification of extra dimensions on a Calabi-Yau manifold preserving four-dimensional supersymmetry or structure.

concepts.label: line bundle
concepts.description: Holomorphic line bundle over the compactification manifold used to define gauge connections and determine the low-energy spectrum.

concepts.label: bosonic spectrum
concepts.description: Collection of bosonic particle states and their masses arising from string compactification.

concepts.label: fermionic spectrum
concepts.description: Collection of fermionic particle states and their masses arising from string compactification.

concepts.label: Green-Schwarz formalism
concepts.description: Covariant superstring formulation preserving manifest spacetime supersymmetry; determines anomaly structure and coupling terms.

concepts.label: axion coupling
concepts.description: Interaction of axion fields with gauge fields and matter, typically induced at loop level in effective field theory.

concepts.label: Standard Model
concepts.description: Gauge theory of particle physics with gauge group SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1) describing electromagnetic, weak, and strong interactions.

concepts.label: Wilson line
concepts.description: Non-trivial holonomy of a gauge connection around a non-contractible loop, used to break gauge symmetry in compactification.

concepts.label: five brane
concepts.description: Extended object with five spatial dimensions (plus time) arising as a solitonic state in string theory.

concepts.label: anomaly factorization
concepts.description: Condition that gravitational and gauge anomalies factorize into contributions from different sectors, constraining allowed brane configurations.

concepts.label: Calabi-Yau manifold
concepts.description: Complex Kähler manifold with vanishing first Chern class used as the standard framework for compactifying supersymmetric string theory.

concepts.label: noncritical manifold
concepts.description: Higher dimensional complex manifold with quantized positive Ricci curvature that does not a priori describe consistent string vacua but can yield massless spectra of critical string groundstates.

concepts.label: supersymmetric string theory
concepts.description: String theory incorporating supersymmetry, requiring compactification of extra dimensions to produce consistent four-dimensional vacua.

concepts.label: Ricci curvature
concepts.description: Geometric invariant measuring the curvature of a Riemannian manifold; quantized positive values characterize noncritical manifolds.

concepts.label: Kähler deformation
concepts.description: Continuous deformation of a Kähler manifold that preserves its complex structure, corresponding to moduli in string compactification.

concepts.label: massless spectrum
concepts.description: Collection of massless excitations and fields in a string theory vacuum, determined by the geometry of the compactification manifold.

concepts.label: string vacuum
concepts.description: Consistent ground state of string theory determined by the choice of compactification manifold and internal structure.

concepts.label: exactly solvable model
concepts.description: Conformal field theory or string model whose spectrum and correlation functions can be computed exactly, often via algebraic methods.

concepts.label: mean field theory
concepts.description: Approximate description of a many-body or field theory system obtained by neglecting fluctuations around a classical background.

concepts.label: Gepner model
concepts.description: Exactly solvable conformal field theory constructed from tensor products of minimal models, related to Calabi-Yau compactifications.

concepts.label: rigid Calabi-Yau
concepts.description: Calabi-Yau manifold with no Kähler deformations, admitting no complex structure moduli and hence no antigenerations.

concepts.label: mirror symmetry
concepts.description: Duality between Calabi-Yau pairs that exchanges complex structure and Kähler deformations, relating pairs of string vacua.

concepts.label: Kaluza-Klein theory
concepts.description: Framework for unifying gravity and gauge theories by compactifying extra spatial dimensions, foundational to dimensional reduction in string theory.

concepts.label: critical string
concepts.description: String theory formulated in the critical dimension (26 for bosonic, 10 for supersymmetric) required for anomaly cancellation and consistency.

concepts.label: log Calabi-Yau compactification
concepts.description: A compactification of a Landau-Ginzburg model that extends the total space to a log Calabi-Yau variety with controlled singularities at infinity.

concepts.label: Landau-Ginzburg model
concepts.description: A pair (Y, W) consisting of a variety Y and a regular function W (superpotential) used in mirror symmetry and algebraic geometry.

concepts.label: Fano variety
concepts.description: A smooth projective variety whose anticanonical divisor is ample, playing a central role in algebraic geometry and mirror symmetry.

concepts.label: del Pezzo surface
concepts.description: A smooth projective surface that is a Fano variety; equivalently, a surface with ample anticanonical divisor.

concepts.label: covering of projective space
concepts.description: A finite surjective morphism from an algebraic variety to projective space; characterised by its degree and ramification data.

concepts.label: anticanonical system
concepts.description: The complete linear system |−K_X| of a variety X, given by the inverse of the canonical divisor; measures the dimension of Fano varieties.

concepts.label: fiber over infinity
concepts.description: The scheme-theoretic preimage of the point at infinity in a compactification, controlling the boundary behaviour of the total space.

concepts.label: singularities
concepts.description: Points in an algebraic variety where the variety is not smooth; characterised by local analytic or algebraic invariants.

concepts.label: total space
concepts.description: The underlying variety in a Landau-Ginzburg model or fibration over which the structure morphism is defined.

concepts.label: Berglund-Hubsch type
concepts.description: A special subclass of Calabi-Yau manifolds characterized by specific algebraic and combinatorial properties enabling exact solvability.

concepts.label: Batyrev-Borisov approach
concepts.description: A combinatorial framework for constructing and studying Calabi-Yau manifolds using reflexive polytopes and mirror symmetry.

concepts.label: Reflexive polytope
concepts.description: A lattice polytope whose polar dual is also a lattice polytope; encodes combinatorial data defining a Calabi-Yau manifold.

concepts.label: SCFT
concepts.description: A superconformal field theory with central charge, used to compactify extra dimensions in string constructions.

concepts.label: Minimal model
concepts.description: A unitary SCFT with central charge c < 3/2, used in Gepner constructions as building blocks for string compactifications.

concepts.label: Vertex operator
concepts.description: An operator in conformal field theory that creates physical states; constructed here as cohomology of Borisov differentials.

concepts.label: Borisov differential
concepts.description: A differential operator associated to points of reflexive polytopes; defines cohomology classes yielding physical vertex operators.

concepts.label: Central charge
concepts.description: A quantum number characterizing the conformal anomaly of a conformal field theory; must satisfy closure conditions in string constructions.

concepts.label: Lie algebra torus
concepts.description: A torus compactification associated with a Lie algebra, used in the right-moving sector of Heterotic strings.

concepts.label: Cohomology
concepts.description: A topological invariant measuring the global structure of manifolds; here used to extract physical states from Borisov data.

concepts.label: heterotic little string theory
concepts.description: A 6D (1,0) quantum field theory that arises as the tensionless limit of heterotic strings, exhibiting rich dualities and generalized symmetries.

concepts.label: Calabi-Yau variety
concepts.description: A complex Kähler manifold with vanishing first Chern class, used in string compactifications and geometric engineering.

concepts.label: K3 surface
concepts.description: A smooth 2-dimensional Calabi-Yau variety with trivial canonical bundle and 22-dimensional moduli space, central to geometric engineering of 6D theories.

concepts.label: F-theory/Heterotic duality
concepts.description: A duality between F-theory on an elliptic fibration and the heterotic string, relating their moduli spaces and symmetries.

concepts.label: 6D (1,0) theory
concepts.description: A six-dimensional quantum field theory with (1,0) supersymmetry, the target space of heterotic little string theories.

concepts.label: T-duality
concepts.description: A duality symmetry relating different string theory compactifications with inverted geometric parameters.

concepts.label: Coulomb branch
concepts.description: The moduli space of vacua in a supersymmetric theory parametrized by scalars in vector multiplets.

concepts.label: flavor symmetry
concepts.description: A global symmetry of a quantum field theory acting on matter fields; in LSTs, determined by the K3 fiber geometry.

concepts.label: Kulikov degeneration
concepts.description: A one-parameter family of K3 surfaces undergoing controlled degeneration to a singular fiber, used to study geometric transitions.

concepts.label: generalized symmetry
concepts.description: Higher-form and categorical symmetries of quantum field theories beyond ordinary Lie group symmetries, including 2-group structures.

concepts.label: geometric engineering
concepts.description: The construction of lower-dimensional quantum field theories from higher-dimensional geometry, typically via string compactification.

concepts.label: realistic compactification conditions
concepts.description: A set of 9 mathematical and physical constraints that bundles on Calabi-Yau manifolds must satisfy to yield realistic 4D physics.

concepts.label: Chern class
concepts.description: A topological invariant of a vector bundle measuring its deviation from triviality; the first Chern class c₁ vanishes for Calabi-Yau manifolds.

concepts.label: supersymmetry preservation
concepts.description: A requirement that a compactification retains some supersymmetry, typically enforced by topological conditions on the bundle.

concepts.label: moduli space
concepts.description: The space of inequivalent geometric structures satisfying given constraints, parameterizing different compactification scenarios.

concepts.label: direct flux breaking
concepts.description: A symmetry breaking mechanism in heterotic string theory achieved via background fluxes on the internal Calabi-Yau manifold.

concepts.label: hypercharge flux
concepts.description: A U(1) flux component in F-theory or heterotic models that breaks electroweak symmetry and couples to the hypercharge gauge boson.

concepts.label: three generations
concepts.description: The three replicated families of quarks and leptons (up-down, charm-strange, top-bottom; electron-electron neutrino, muon-muon neutrino, tau-tau neutrino) observed in nature.

concepts.label: chiral exotics
concepts.description: Extra massless fermions transforming under the Standard Model gauge group but absent in the observable spectrum; their absence is phenomenologically required.

concepts.label: background independence
concepts.description: A derivation or formula that does not depend on choosing a particular geometric moduli or background representative.

concepts.label: gauge symmetry breaking
concepts.description: Spontaneous or explicit reduction of the gauge group to a subgroup via vacuum expectation values or background fields.

concepts.label: Fiber/base exchange
concepts.description: A geometric symmetry in F-theory relating the elliptic fibration structure by swapping the role of the fiber and base spaces.

concepts.label: F-theory vacuum
concepts.description: A consistent vacuum state or compactification background in F-theory characterized by a specific Calabi-Yau geometry and flux data.

concepts.label: Argyres-Douglas point
concepts.description: A special point in N=2 gauge theory moduli space where massless monopoles and dyons collide, signaling enhanced non-perturbative dynamics.

concepts.label: Transition point
concepts.description: A locus in the moduli space where distinct vacua or phases become degenerate, potentially signaling singular geometry or enhanced symmetry.

concepts.label: U(n) vector bundles
concepts.description: Holomorphic vector bundles with unitary structure group on complex manifolds, used to define gauge theories in string compactifications.

concepts.label: spectral data
concepts.description: Algebraic-geometric data encoding the structure of holomorphic bundles, typically via spectral curves or related constructions.

concepts.label: stability
concepts.description: A condition on vector bundles (Mumford or slope stability) ensuring they form a well-defined moduli space.

concepts.label: characteristic classes
concepts.description: Cohomological invariants of vector bundles (e.g., Chern classes) that classify topological types.

concepts.label: bundle cohomology
concepts.description: Sheaf cohomology groups H^i(X, E) measuring sections and global properties of a vector bundle E.

concepts.label: Donaldson-Uhlenbeck-Yau equation
concepts.description: A gauge-theoretic PDE ensuring existence of Hermitian-Einstein metrics on vector bundles, equivalent to stability.

concepts.label: heterotic anomaly cancellation
concepts.description: Topological constraint requiring that the tangent bundle and gauge bundle satisfy c₂(T)=c₂(E), ensuring anomaly-free compactification.

concepts.label: net-generation number
concepts.description: Difference between generations of chiral fermions arising from bundle moduli in heterotic compactifications.

concepts.label: five-branes
concepts.description: Five-dimensional topological defects in string theory that contribute to anomaly cancellation and modify the moduli space.

concepts.label: F-theory model
concepts.description: Twelve-dimensional model dual to heterotic string theory, related by duality and describing D-brane moduli.

concepts.label: three-branes
concepts.description: Three-dimensional topological defects in F-theory that appear as dual partners to heterotic five-branes.

concepts.label: F-theory compactification
concepts.description: Compactification of F-theory on an elliptic fibration to obtain lower-dimensional effective theories with rich physics including gauge symmetries and matter content.

concepts.label: 3-brane probe
concepts.description: A D3-brane or similar extended object used as a probe to explore the geometry and gauge structure of string theory compactifications.

concepts.label: field theory on probe
concepts.description: The effective quantum field theory arising on the world-volume of a probe brane in a string theory compactification.

concepts.label: electric-magnetic duality
concepts.description: Symmetry exchanging electric and magnetic charges and operators in a gauge theory, generalizing electromagnetic duality to non-abelian theories.

concepts.label: spacetime theory
concepts.description: The effective theory describing low-energy dynamics in the full higher-dimensional space-time before compactification.

concepts.label: parallel brane configuration
concepts.description: A geometric arrangement of multiple probe branes positioned parallel to one another in a compactification geometry.

concepts.label: string theory
concepts.description: Fundamental framework treating elementary particles as one-dimensional extended objects (strings) propagating through higher-dimensional space-time.

concepts.label: bosonic string
concepts.description: Classical string theory without fermionic degrees of freedom; fundamental object with kinetic and interaction terms.

concepts.label: D-brane
concepts.description: Extended object in string theory on which open strings can terminate; characterized by its spatial dimension and properties.

concepts.label: M-theory
concepts.description: Eleven-dimensional non-perturbative framework unifying all five superstring theories; contains closed and open membranes.

concepts.label: brane box configuration
concepts.description: String theory construction using intersecting D-branes arranged spatially; encodes gauge symmetries and matter spectrum.

concepts.label: string spectrum
concepts.description: Collection of all allowed quantum excitations of strings, including massless and massive modes; determines low-energy effective field theory.

concepts.label: effective action
concepts.description: Low-energy action describing massless modes of string theory; governs four-dimensional physics.

concepts.label: Grand Unified Theory
concepts.description: Extension of Standard Model unifying gauge interactions at high scales via enlarged symmetry groups.

concepts.label: Kähler structure
concepts.description: Geometric structure on a complex manifold combining a Riemannian metric with a compatible symplectic form; defines the Kähler class.

concepts.label: non-Kähler geometry
concepts.description: Complex manifold structure lacking the Kähler property; generalizes Calabi-Yau compactifications beyond the Kähler case.

concepts.label: twistor space
concepts.description: Auxiliary geometric space encoding conformal structures of lower-dimensional manifolds; fibers are Riemann spheres parameterized by the base manifold.

concepts.label: branched double cover
concepts.description: Topological construction where a manifold is constructed as a double cover ramified over a codimension-2 subspace of the base space.

concepts.label: self-dual conformal structure
concepts.description: Conformal geometry on four-manifolds where the Weyl tensor equals its Hodge dual; characterized by zero anti-self-dual part.

concepts.label: connected sum
concepts.description: Topological operation gluing two manifolds together by removing balls and identifying boundaries; denoted by #.

concepts.label: blow-up
concepts.description: Geometric operation replacing a point with a complex projective line; resolves singularities or modifies the twistor space.

concepts.label: K3-fibration
concepts.description: Fibered manifold where each fiber is a K3 surface; used to construct higher-dimensional Calabi-Yau manifolds with K3 fibers.

concepts.label: heterotic string compactification
concepts.description: Compactification of heterotic string theory on Calabi-Yau manifolds to reduce ten-dimensional theory to four dimensions.

concepts.label: stable vector bundle
concepts.description: Holomorphic vector bundle where every subbundle of positive rank has slope strictly less than the bundle slope; satisfies slope-stability condition.

concepts.label: polystable vector bundle
concepts.description: Direct sum of stable vector bundles with equal slope; generalizes stability to allow direct sums of stable bundles.

concepts.label: supersymmetric model
concepts.description: Gauge theory or string compactification preserving supersymmetry; matches fermion and boson spectrum at each energy scale.

concepts.label: generations of fermions
concepts.description: Copies of the fundamental fermionic matter content (quarks and leptons); the Standard Model contains three generations.

concepts.label: NS flux
concepts.description: Neveu-Schwarz two-form flux in string theory; a background field present in compactifications that preserves N=1 supersymmetry in four dimensions.

concepts.label: domain wall
concepts.description: A four-dimensional topological soliton solution representing an interface between regions with different vacuum states, with translational invariance in one less spatial direction.

concepts.label: moduli stabilization
concepts.description: The mechanism by which massless moduli fields (internal geometry deformations) acquire mass through interactions with fluxes and other fields, fixing geometric parameters.

concepts.label: flux potential
concepts.description: The scalar potential energy arising from the interaction of fluxes with the geometry and matter content in string theory.

concepts.label: runaway direction
concepts.description: A modulus field whose potential energy decreases monotonically in some direction, preventing stabilization and breaking supersymmetry.

concepts.label: four-dimensional supergravity
concepts.description: An effective field theory in four spacetime dimensions with local N=1 supersymmetry, derived from string theory compactifications.

concepts.label: maximally symmetric spacetime
concepts.description: A four-dimensional background with the maximum number of isometries (typically Minkowski, de Sitter, or anti-de Sitter).

concepts.label: domain-wall supersymmetry breaking
concepts.description: Technique for constructing non-supersymmetric vacua via domain-wall defects that break SUSY at specific locations in the compactified geometry.

concepts.label: flux compactifications
concepts.description: Compactification geometry where background fluxes (closed p-form fields) are turned on in the extra dimensions, stabilizing moduli and breaking symmetries.

concepts.label: intrinsic torsion
concepts.description: Non-vanishing torsion tensor present in generalized geometry or Calabi-Yau manifolds with non-zero NS-NS flux, characterizing non-Kähler structures.

concepts.label: non-supersymmetric vacua
concepts.description: Vacuum configurations that break supersymmetry while maintaining metastability or satisfying equations of motion in string theory.

concepts.label: compactification manifold
concepts.description: Internal geometric space (typically 6-dimensional in heterotic theory) on which extra dimensions are compactified.

concepts.label: equations of motion
concepts.description: Field equations derived from the action principle that determine the physical configurations and consistency conditions of the theory.

concepts.label: type II compactifications
concepts.description: String theory compactifications using type II superstrings (IIA/IIB), to which DWSB technique was originally applied.

concepts.label: alpha-prime corrections
concepts.description: Higher-derivative stringy corrections to low-energy effective actions, organized as expansion in the string length scale α'.

concepts.label: background fluxes
concepts.description: Non-zero vacuum expectation values of closed differential forms (NS-NS and RR sectors) threading the compactification geometry.

concepts.label: stringy cosmic strings
concepts.description: Topological defect solutions in string theory arising from compactifications; extended one-dimensional objects with tension from string scale physics.

concepts.label: ten dimensional spacetime
concepts.description: The background spacetime geometry of type IIB superstring theory comprising ten coordinates.

concepts.label: topological defect
concepts.description: A stable, localized solution in field theory or string theory topologically prevented from unwinding, such as strings or domain walls.

concepts.label: gerbe
concepts.description: A stack-theoretic generalization of spaces that locally looks like a quotient by a group action; admits more bundles than the underlying space.

concepts.label: stack
concepts.description: A categorical generalization of topological spaces and schemes that keeps track of automorphisms and quotient structures via groupoids.

concepts.label: gauge theory
concepts.description: Field theory with local symmetry under a Lie group; emerges as the low-energy effective theory from string compactification.

concepts.label: orbifold
concepts.description: A singular space obtained as a quotient of a smooth space by a discrete group action; a special case of stack.

concepts.label: perturbative consistency
concepts.description: The requirement that a compactification yields a well-defined low-energy effective theory without anomalies or infrared divergences.

concepts.label: disjoint union
concepts.description: Topological coproduct combining multiple spaces with no shared points; used here to describe decomposable gerbe compactifications.

concepts.label: building block
concepts.description: Elementary or irreducible geometric component from which more complex gerbe compactifications are constructed.

concepts.label: Type IIB string theory
concepts.description: Ten-dimensional superstring theory with two identical sets of supersymmetries; one of the five consistent string theories.

concepts.label: Large volume limit
concepts.description: Regime where the compactification manifold has a large geometric volume, leading to a decoupled effective field theory.

concepts.label: SL(2,Z) symmetry
concepts.description: Discrete duality symmetry group of type IIB string theory that exchanges strong and weak coupling regimes through S-duality.

concepts.label: Type IIA string theory
concepts.description: Ten-dimensional superstring theory with two opposite sets of supersymmetries; related to type IIB by mirror symmetry.

concepts.label: Mirror Calabi-Yau
concepts.description: Dual Calabi-Yau manifold exchanging complex structure and Kähler moduli with the original CY threefold.

concepts.label: Worldsheet
concepts.description: Two-dimensional surface swept out by a string in spacetime; fundamental to string theory dynamics and worldsheet instanton effects.

concepts.label: Complex structure moduli
concepts.description: Scalar fields parametrising the complex-geometric deformations of the Calabi-Yau manifold topology.

concepts.label: AdS minimum
concepts.description: Vacuum state with negative cosmological constant in an anti-de Sitter spacetime, corresponding to a local minimum of the potential.

concepts.label: de Sitter uplift
concepts.description: Perturbative or non-perturbative contribution lifting an AdS vacuum to a metastable de Sitter state with small positive cosmological constant.

concepts.label: Tachyon-free condition
concepts.description: Requirement that all scalar field masses are non-negative (squared mass matrix positive semi-definite) to ensure vacuum stability.

concepts.label: KKLT scenario
concepts.description: Moduli stabilisation framework combining SUGRA potential, non-perturbative effects, and uplifting to construct de Sitter vacua in string theory.

concepts.label: Gravitino mass
concepts.description: Mass of the fermionic superpartner of the graviton; controls the scale of supersymmetry breaking in the theory.

concepts.label: Flux discretuum
concepts.description: Discrete set of allowed flux configurations satisfying quantisation and tadpole cancellation conditions, parameterising the string landscape.

concepts.label: String scale
concepts.description: Fundamental length scale (inverse mass scale) at which string-theoretic effects become important, set by the string coupling and compactification geometry.

concepts.label: Planck scale
concepts.description: Fundamental mass scale of quantum gravity in four dimensions, related to Newton's gravitational constant.

concepts.label: Standard Model spectrum
concepts.description: The chiral fermion content and gauge group structure (SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1)) of the Standard Model of particle physics.

concepts.label: Gauge coupling unification
concepts.description: The condition that the three gauge couplings of the Standard Model unify at a high energy scale, a prediction of Grand Unified Theories.

concepts.label: Calabi-Yau fourfold
concepts.description: A complex four-dimensional Kähler manifold with vanishing first Chern class, used as the internal geometry in F-theory compactifications to six dimensions.

concepts.label: Toric base
concepts.description: The base of an elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau manifold defined combinatorially via a toric variety, allowing explicit enumeration and classification.

concepts.label: Global consistency conditions
concepts.description: Mathematical constraints that must be satisfied for a string compactification to define a valid, anomaly-free effective field theory.

concepts.label: Polytope
concepts.description: A convex geometric object defined by linear inequalities; in toric geometry, encodes the combinatorial data of a toric variety.

concepts.label: Algebraic geometry
concepts.description: The mathematical framework studying varieties defined by polynomial equations, used here to characterize geometric constraints on F-theory compactifications.

concepts.label: infinitely divisible random field
concepts.description: A random field whose distribution can be expressed as the n-th convolution power of some probability distribution for all positive integers n.

concepts.label: integral representation
concepts.description: A mathematical formulation expressing a random field as an integral of deterministic functions with respect to a random measure.

concepts.label: infinitely divisible random measure
concepts.description: A random measure whose characteristic functional is infinitely divisible, allowing for decomposition into convolution powers.

concepts.label: deterministic function
concepts.description: A non-random mathematical function used as an integrand in the integral representation of random fields.

concepts.label: probability distribution
concepts.description: A mathematical function describing the likelihood of different outcomes of a random variable or field.

concepts.label: convolution
concepts.description: A mathematical operation combining two functions or distributions; the n-fold convolution power describes repeated convolution.

concepts.label: random field
concepts.description: A collection of random variables indexed by points in a multi-dimensional space or domain.

concepts.label: characteristic functional
concepts.description: A functional that uniquely characterizes the distribution of a random field, analogous to the characteristic function for random variables.

concepts.label: reflexive polyhedra
concepts.description: Four-dimensional lattice polytopes whose polar duals are also lattice polytopes, encoding data for smooth Calabi-Yau hypersurfaces.

concepts.label: toric variety
concepts.description: Algebraic variety with a dense torus action, used to embed Calabi-Yau hypersurfaces via reflexive polyhedra.

concepts.label: singular transition
concepts.description: Geometric transition between Calabi-Yau manifolds via conifold singularities or flops that preserve or modify topological invariants.

concepts.label: perturbative string theory
concepts.description: String theory calculations in a weak coupling regime based on expansions in the string coupling constant.

concepts.label: hypersurface
concepts.description: Codimension-one algebraic subvariety defined as the zero locus of a single polynomial equation.

concepts.label: lattice polytope
concepts.description: A convex polytope whose vertices are integer lattice points.

concepts.label: polar dual
concepts.description: The geometric dual of a lattice polytope defined by the perpendicularity condition with respect to the integer lattice.

concepts.label: Swampland Distance Conjecture
concepts.description: A conjecture stating that effective theories from consistent quantum gravity have only finite range of validity in field space.

concepts.label: Refined Swampland Distance Conjecture
concepts.description: A refined version of the SDC claiming that the finite range of validity is bounded by the Planck scale.

concepts.label: effective field theory
concepts.description: A low-energy theory derived from a fundamental theory of quantum gravity with limited validity range.

concepts.label: quantum gravity
concepts.description: A fundamental theory that combines quantum mechanics with general relativity, providing consistent rules for gravitational interactions.

concepts.label: Kähler moduli space
concepts.description: The space of parameters controlling Kähler deformations of a Calabi-Yau manifold.

concepts.label: non-geometric phase
concepts.description: A region of moduli space where the standard geometric description of Calabi-Yau compactification breaks down.

concepts.label: field distance
concepts.description: The metric distance in field space between two points in the moduli space of an effective field theory.

concepts.label: model building
concepts.description: The process of constructing phenomenologically viable particle physics models from string theory.

concepts.label: de Sitter space
concepts.description: A cosmological solution with positive vacuum energy density, characterized by exponential expansion and a positive cosmological constant.

concepts.label: warped compactification
concepts.description: A mechanism for reducing extra dimensions in string theory where the metric is non-uniform in the transverse direction, creating a warping factor.

concepts.label: three-form flux
concepts.description: Antisymmetric tensor field backgrounds (NS and RR) threading compactified dimensions, providing quantized contributions to the effective potential.

concepts.label: superpotential
concepts.description: A holomorphic function encoding the interactions and mass terms in a supersymmetric effective action.

concepts.label: Euclidean D-brane instanton
concepts.description: Non-perturbative effect from wrapped Euclidean D-branes contributing exponentially suppressed terms to the superpotential.

concepts.label: gaugino condensation
concepts.description: Non-perturbative phenomenon where fermionic partners of gauge bosons develop a non-zero vacuum expectation value, generating a superpotential term.

concepts.label: anti-D3 brane
concepts.description: Topological defect carrying opposite charge to D3-branes; inclusion uplifts AdS minima through repulsive interactions.

concepts.label: AdS/CFT correspondence
concepts.description: Gauge-gravity duality relating anti-de Sitter spacetime to a conformal field theory living on its boundary.

concepts.label: metastable vacuum
concepts.description: A local minimum of the potential with finite lifetime via quantum tunneling or thermal activation to a lower-energy state.

concepts.label: recurrence time
concepts.description: The Poincaré recurrence timescale over which a thermodynamic system returns arbitrarily close to its initial state.

edges.evidence: The paper develops techniques to understand duality between heterotic string and F theory compactifications.
Duality between heterotic string and F theory compactifications is the focus of detailed comparisons.
F theory compactifications are defined via compactification on elliptic Calabi-Yau manifolds.
Heterotic string compactifications on elliptic Calabi-Yau manifolds are central to the duality with F theory.
Holomorphic G bundles over elliptic Calabi-Yau manifolds are used to describe heterotic string compactifications.
The paper develops techniques to describe holomorphic G bundles over elliptic Calabi-Yau manifolds.
Holomorphic G bundles have structure group G for various groups; the choice of G determines the bundle type.
Elliptic Calabi-Yau manifolds are characterized by admitting elliptic fibration structure.
F theory is defined via compactification of type IIB string theory on elliptic fibrations.
Heterotic string requires compactification on six-dimensional Calabi-Yau manifolds.
The Hodge numbers h^{p,q} are topological invariants that characterise Calabi-Yau threefolds; the authors compute these numbers for various threefolds.
Calabi-Yau threefolds are defined to have holonomy groups that are precisely SU(3), distinguishing them from manifolds with subgroups of SU(3).
The paper specifies that the holonomy group equals SU(3) rather than a proper subgroup thereof.
The authors classify Calabi-Yau threefolds by their height; small height is the criterion for inclusion in the list.
Complete intersection Calabi-Yau threefolds form a class of Calabi-Yau threefolds; the paper computes Hodge numbers for free quotients of these.
Free quotients of complete intersection Calabi-Yau threefolds are constructed as new examples; the paper computes their Hodge numbers.
The authors plot Calabi-Yau threefolds on the Hodge plot according to their Hodge numbers, updating previous plots by Davies and Candelas.
The main computational project completed is the computation of Hodge numbers for free quotients of complete intersection Calabi-Yau threefolds.
F-theory compactifications on certain Calabi-Yau threefolds are the primary subject of study.
Type II/heterotic string dualities in 4 dimensions exist and are promoted in the F-theory setup.
Type II/heterotic dualities get promoted to dualities between heterotic string and F-theory in 6 dimensions.
Four-dimensional type II/heterotic dualities are promoted to six-dimensional heterotic/F-theory dualities.
F-theory sheds light on the strong coupling transition and what lies beyond it at finite heterotic coupling values.
The F-theory compactification provides insight into the nature of strong coupling transitions in heterotic string.
The strong coupling transition occurs at finite values of the heterotic string coupling constant.
Six-dimensional heterotic/heterotic duality becomes a classical geometric symmetry of the Calabi-Yau in F-theory.
F-theory is a non-perturbative formulation enabling geometric treatment of strong coupling regimes beyond perturbation theory.
Strong coupling transitions involve non-perturbative physics that cannot be accessed perturbatively.
SO(16)×SO(16) is one of three ten-dimensional heterotic string formulations discussed throughout.
E8×E8 is a standard ten-dimensional heterotic string theory.
SO(32) is the third ten-dimensional heterotic string formulation examined in the paper.
The paper studies smooth compactifications of heterotic theories on Calabi-Yau manifolds to extract low-energy physics.
Compactifications with line bundles are exploited to determine the bosonic and fermionic spectra.
The authors determine the bosonic spectrum of Calabi-Yau compactifications of the non-supersymmetric string.
The authors determine the fermionic spectrum of Calabi-Yau compactifications of the non-supersymmetric string.
Line bundle structure determines the gauge connection and resulting spectrum of low-energy states.
The authors use Green-Schwarz formalism to determine the axion-couplings induced at leading order.
The authors construct a Standard Model-like theory from non-supersymmetric SO(16)×SO(16) compactifications.
SM-like models are obtained from the standard embedding using at least an order four Wilson line.
The paper makes a proposal of the states that live on five branes in SO(16)×SO(16) theory.
Anomaly factorization admits at most a single brane solution under certain assumptions.
The paper exploits similarities between the non-supersymmetric SO(16)×SO(16) and supersymmetric E8×E8 theories.
Noncritical manifolds provide a framework for compactification that extends beyond the standard Calabi-Yau approach, yielding massless spectra of critical string groundstates.
The geometry of the compactification manifold determines the massless excitations in the resulting four-dimensional theory.
Calabi-Yau manifolds are the standard framework for string compactification in the critical theory.
The new class of noncritical theories is more general than Calabi-Yau manifolds and can be used to construct them as a subclass.
Noncritical manifolds are spaces with quantized positive Ricci curvature.
Kähler deformations of the compactification manifold correspond to distinct string vacua; rigid Calabi-Yau manifolds with no Kähler deformations provide vacua with no antigenerations.
Mirror symmetry relates pairs of Calabi-Yau manifolds; rigid Calabi-Yau manifolds now have mirrors among noncritical theories.
Noncritical theories provide mirrors of rigid Calabi-Yau manifolds, which correspond to critical string vacua with no Kähler deformations.
The constructions lead to new insight into the relation between exactly solvable models and Calabi-Yau manifolds.
Gepner models are exactly solvable conformal field theories; modifications of Gepner's conjecture are mentioned in relation to the new noncritical framework.
New insight is gained into the relation between exactly solvable models and their mean field theories.
The framework reviewed concerns the compactification of supersymmetric string theory on noncritical manifolds.
Noncritical manifolds can derive the massless spectra of critical string groundstates.
The new framework raises fundamental questions about the Kaluza-Klein concept of string compactification and the role of internal dimension.
The paper constructs log Calabi-Yau compactifications of weak Landau-Ginzburg models, embedding them into a larger algebraic structure.
Log Calabi-Yau compactifications are constructed from Landau-Ginzburg models of Fano varieties.
Del Pezzo surfaces are defined as smooth projective surfaces whose anticanonical divisor is ample, making them special Fano varieties.
A Fano variety is fundamentally defined by the ampleness of its anticanonical divisor; the dimension of the anticanonical system is a key invariant.
Coverings of projective spaces of index one are studied as examples of varieties with Fano geometry, applied in the compactification procedure.
For coverings of degree greater than 2, the log Calabi-Yau compactification is singular; no smooth projective log Calabi-Yau compactification exists.
The number of components of the fiber over infinity equals the dimension of the anticanonical system of the Fano variety.
The fiber over infinity is a natural component of the compactification structure, controlling boundary behaviour.
A Landau-Ginzburg model is a pair (Y, W) where Y is the total space on which the superpotential W is defined.
Landau-Ginzburg models are central objects in mirror symmetry dualities and compactification constructions.
Heterotic string models in lower dimensions are obtained by compactifying extra dimensions on Calabi-Yau manifold SCFTs
CY manifolds of Berglund-Hubsch type form a special subclass of general Calabi-Yau manifolds
The Batyrev-Borisov combinatorial approach is used to construct and study Calabi-Yau manifolds of Berglund-Hubsch type
A reflexive Batyrev polytope determines the data of the corresponding Calabi-Yau manifold
Vertex operators of the complete physical theory are constructed as cohomology of Borisov differentials
Borisov differentials correspond to points of reflexive Batyrev polyhedra
Gepner constructions are an important class of exactly solvable Heterotic string models using minimal model products
Gepner models are constructed as products of minimal models with total central charge c=9
Mirror pairs of Batyrev lattices are used in the combinatorial approach to encode mirror symmetry
Left and right moving sectors compactify on SCFT theories with specific central charges
SCFT theories are characterized by their central charge values that must satisfy closure constraints
Remaining dimensions in Heterotic strings are compactified on the torus of a Lie algebra
The number of representations and vertex operators is determined by data of the reflexive Batyrev polytope
Cohomology of Borisov differentials provides the construction of physical vertex operators
LSTs are 6D (1,0) quantum field theories that arise as the tensionless limit of heterotic strings.
F-theory provides a framework for geometric engineering of heterotic little string theories using elliptic fibrations.
The 6D systems correspond to non-compact elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau varieties.
Calabi-Yau varieties must admit the structure of an elliptic K3 fibration.
From fiberwise F-theory/Heterotic duality the K3 plays a central role in determining 6D properties.
The K3 fiber determines the 6D flavor group of the LST.
Inequivalent elliptic fibration structures lead to different T-dual LSTs.
The point where the K3 fiber degenerates is the locus where the LST arises, via finer versions of Kulikov degenerations.
Field theory predictions on LST dualities are checked via match of Coulomb branch dimension.
Recent progress in understanding 6D (1,0) theories and their generalized symmetries enables solving open questions about LSTs.
Generalized symmetries including 2-group structures characterize 6D (1,0) theories.
F-theory/Heterotic duality is used to geometrically engineer heterotic little string theories and explore their dualities.
Non-compact elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau varieties correspond to 6D (1,0) LST systems.
Examples are given of bundles on Calabi-Yau 3-folds satisfying conditions for string theory compactifications.
Calabi-Yau 3-folds are used as compactification spaces to reduce string theory from 10 to 4 dimensions.
Bundles on Calabi-Yau 3-folds are essential ingredients for realistic string theory compactifications.
Bundles must satisfy 8 out of 9 conditions required for realistic compactification of string theory.
A Calabi-Yau 3-fold is defined by having vanishing first Chern class.
The structure of the vector bundle determines the gauge group of the compactified theory.
Realistic compactifications typically preserve some supersymmetry, a condition enforced on bundles.
Calabi-Yau compactifications with vector bundles provide the natural framework for heterotic string theory.
The moduli space parametrizes inequivalent compactification scenarios satisfying given constraints.
We study a direct flux breaking scenario in SO(32) heterotic string theory on general Calabi-Yau threefolds.
Direct flux breaking is a symmetry breaking mechanism achieved via background fluxes.
The direct flux breaking, corresponding to hypercharge flux breaking in the F-theory context.
The direct flux breaking allows us to derive the Standard Model in general Calabi-Yau compactifications.
Compactification on Calabi-Yau threefolds enables derivation of the Standard Model.
A general formula leading to the three generations of quarks and leptons.
Direct flux breaking leads to the three generations of quarks and leptons.
The mechanism achieves three generations and no chiral exotics in a background-independent way.
As a concrete example, we show the three-generation model on a complete intersection Calabi-Yau threefold.
The formula leading to three generations holds in a background-independent way.
Hypercharge flux breaking is understood in the F-theory context.
F-theory duals of heterotic strings and recipe for building F-theory duals for arbitrary heterotic compactifications.
Heterotic compactifications on elliptically fibered manifolds mapped to F-theory duals.
String/string duality in six dimensions gets mapped to fiber/base exchange in F-theory.
Fiber/base exchange describes a geometric symmetry of elliptic fibrations in F-theory.
Construction of new N=2 and N=1 examples of F-theory vacua.
Transition points correspond upon further compactification to transitions through analogues of Argyres-Douglas points of N=2 moduli.
Classifying N=5 fivebranes of heterotic strings is key to understanding transitions.
Further compactification to 4 dimensions produces moduli spaces where transitions occur.
Calabi-Yau geometries and their variations characterize the moduli space of F-theory vacua.
The paper provides an explicit description of U(n) vector bundles on elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau threefolds.
Elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau threefolds are a special class of Calabi-Yau threefolds.
An explicit description of the spectral data of stable U(n) vector bundles is given.
The stability and dimension of the moduli space of the U(n) bundles are discussed.
Stable bundles form a well-defined moduli space; stability is discussed alongside moduli space dimension.
The characteristic classes of U(n) bundles are computed.
Part of the bundle cohomology is shown to vanish.
Various explicit solutions of the Donaldson-Uhlenbeck-Yau equation are given.
U(n) bundles are capable to solve the basic topological constraints imposed by heterotic string theory.
The heterotic anomaly cancellation condition is analyzed for U(n) bundles.
An integral change in the number of fiber wrapping five-branes is found from anomaly cancellation analysis.
Five-branes in heterotic theory correspond to three-branes in a dual F-theory model.
The analysis gives predictions for three-branes in a dual F-theory model.
The net-generation number is evaluated, showing more flexibility compared with the SU(n) case.
The compactification geometry determines the structure of the world-volume theory on probe branes.
The field theory on the probe is the effective world-volume theory of the 3-brane.
String theory provides simple pictures of the spacetime theory arising from compactifications.
Implications of the spacetime theory constrain the structure of three-brane world-volume theories.
F-theory on configurations with intersecting singularities yields unusual N=1 superconformal theories on the probe.
One configuration involves several parallel 3-brane probes, generalizing previous work.
The field theory on the probe in the second case is an N=1 superconformal theory.
The N=1 superconformal theory possesses exact electric-magnetic duality.
String theory framework is used to analyze F-theory compactifications and derive field theory predictions.
Gauge symmetries in field theories emerge from the geometric structure of F-theory compactifications.
Superstring theory incorporates fermionic degrees of freedom absent in bosonic string; five perturbative superstring theories exist.
The spectrum is briefly outlined for each of the five perturbative superstring theories.
Calabi-Yau three-fold compactifications of heterotic strings are described with relation to four-dimensional physics.
Compactification determines the low-energy four-dimensional effective field theory from ten-dimensional string action.
Relation between Calabi-Yau compactifications and four-dimensional physics connecting to Standard Model phenomenology.
T-duality in closed and open strings is surveyed as fundamental property of string theories.
Brane box configurations involve D-branes arranged to produce gauge symmetries and matter.
Open strings terminating on D-branes contribute states to the string spectrum.
S-duality relates superstring theories at strong and weak coupling; M-theory provides non-perturbative unification.
M-theory unifies all five perturbative superstring theories in a non-perturbative eleven-dimensional framework.
F-theory provides non-perturbative formulation with elliptic fibrations relevant for Calabi-Yau compactifications.
Non-perturbative Calabi-Yau compactifications of M-theory are discussed as foundational topic.
Heterotic string compactifications naturally accommodate GUT structures relevant to particle physics.
Brane box configurations encode gauge symmetries and matter spectrum; cube model exemplifies application to realistic physics.
We propose a construction of Kähler and non-Kähler Calabi-Yau manifolds by branched double covers of twistor spaces.
Using twistor spaces of four-manifolds with self-dual conformal structures as the base for branched double covers.
Twistor spaces are constructed from four-manifolds with self-dual conformal structures.
Examples of twistor spaces from connected sums of four-manifolds are used in the construction.
K3-fibered Calabi-Yau manifolds are constructed from branched double covers of blow-ups of twistor spaces.
K3-fibered manifolds with appropriate base geometry constitute a class of Calabi-Yau manifolds.
Kähler Calabi-Yau manifolds possess both Kähler and Calabi-Yau properties; we construct both Kähler and non-Kähler variants.
Non-Kähler Calabi-Yau manifolds extend the Calabi-Yau class beyond Kähler constraints.
These manifolds can be used in heterotic string compactifications to four dimensions.
Stable and polystable vector bundles constructed on these manifolds are used in heterotic compactifications.
Polystable bundles are direct sums of stable bundles, generalizing the stability condition.
Some classes of stable and polystable vector bundles can give rise to supersymmetric grand unified models.
Supersymmetric grand unified models are discussed as outputs of the vector bundle construction.
The vector bundle construction yields supersymmetric grand unified models with three generations of quarks and leptons.
Compactifications of the heterotic string with NS flux are the subject of study.
An internal Calabi-Yau manifold is consistent with the presence of NS flux in heterotic compactifications.
Compactifications with NS flux normally require non-Kähler internal spaces; Kähler condition is relaxed when flux is present.
An internal Calabi-Yau manifold is consistent with NS flux provided four-dimensional spacetime is a domain wall.
The conclusion that NS flux requires non-Kähler spaces rests on assumption of maximally symmetric four-dimensional spacetime, which can be relaxed.
Calabi-Yau domain wall solutions are consistent with NS flux when spacetime is taken to be a domain wall rather than maximally symmetric.
Domain wall solutions can be associated with a covariant four-dimensional N=1 supergravity.
The domain wall arises as the simplest solution to effective supergravity due to the presence of a flux potential with a runaway direction.
Flux potential exhibits a runaway direction in the moduli space.
NS flux is a legitimate ingredient for moduli stabilization in heterotic Calabi-Yau models.
Success of models depends on the ability to stabilize the runaway direction and lift the domain wall to a maximally supersymmetric vacuum.
Calabi-Yau manifolds serve as internal spaces for compactifying heterotic string.
DWSB technique constructs non-supersymmetric vacua in heterotic compactifications.
DWSB technique was developed in type II context and here applied to heterotic theory.
Investigation of heterotic string compactifications with intrinsic torsion and background fluxes.
Compactifications with fluxes exhibit intrinsic torsion in the internal geometry.
Scalar potential is derived from background fluxes and compactification geometry.
Scalar potential used to derive conditions that satisfy equations of motion up to order α'.
Conditions on the compactification manifold must be satisfied for EOM consistency.
EOM are satisfied up to order α', indicating higher-derivative corrections are included.
Intrinsic torsion affects the structure of the derived scalar potential.
DWSB technique applied to construct non-supersymmetric vacua in heterotic string compactifications.
F-theory is compactified on elliptic Calabi-Yau manifolds; this is the defining structure of the compactification.
The ten dimensional type IIB superstring theory has a low energy effective action from which equations of motion are derived.
Stringy cosmic string solutions correspond to and arise from compactifications of F-theory on elliptic Calabi-Yau manifolds.
Equations of motion are derived by varying the low energy effective action of ten dimensional type IIB theory.
Stringy cosmic string solutions are obtained by solving the equations of motion of the effective action.
Cosmic strings are topological defects arising in field theory and string theory compactifications.
Type IIB superstring theory is fundamentally formulated in ten dimensional spacetime.
F-theory compactifications relate to type IIB superstring theory; the effective action is ten dimensional IIB.
A heterotic string compactification determines the low-energy gauge theory and massless matter content.
Heterotic string compactifications on gerbes are a generalization of compactifications on spaces, admitting more bundles.
A gerbe is a special class of stack; the paper works out aspects of heterotic strings on stacks and specializes to gerbes.
Gerbes admit more bundles than corresponding spaces, making them a rich playground for compactifications.
The spectrum of massless fields is computed from the geometry of the compactification space.
A subgroup of the gauge group acts trivially on the massless matter in gerbe compactifications, restricting the spectrum.
A compactification on a gerbe can be understood as imposing restrictions on nonperturbative sectors.
Orbifolds are a special case of stacks; the paper derives consistency conditions for heterotic strings on orbifolds.
The paper considers three classes of building blocks of which gerbe compactifications are composed.
Some gerbe compactifications are equivalent to or dual to compactifications on different spaces or other heterotic strings.
One class of building blocks is not perturbatively consistent, limiting the new compactifications obtainable from gerbes.
One class of gerbe compactifications is equivalent to compactifications on a disjoint union of spaces.
Vector bundles are central geometric data in defining a heterotic string compactification; the paper reviews bundle properties on gerbes.
Study compactifications of type IIB supergravity on Calabi-Yau threefolds
The resulting low energy effective Lagrangian is displayed
The resulting low energy effective Lagrangian is displayed in the large volume limit
Its symmetry properties - with specific emphasis on the SL(2,Z) - are discussed
Explicit map to type IIA string theory compactified on a mirror Calabi-Yau is derived
Explicit map to type IIA string theory compactified on a mirror Calabi-Yau
Type IIA string theory compactified on a mirror Calabi-Yau
Explicit map to type IIA string theory compactified on a mirror Calabi-Yau is derived
Explicit map to type IIA string theory compactified on a mirror Calabi-Yau is derived
Strong coupling effects on the worldsheet break the SL(2,Z)
Strong coupling effects on the worldsheet break the SL(2,Z)
Flux compactifications of type IIB string theory generate a scalar potential for moduli (abstract, main claim).
The potential structure allows fixing Kähler and complex structure moduli, which has been difficult to achieve in the KKLT scenario.
Study of the large volume limit of the scalar potential in Calabi-Yau flux compactifications; potential approaches zero from below in this regime.
In the large volume limit there exists a non-supersymmetric AdS minimum at exponentially large volume.
Both the AdS minimum and its de Sitter uplift fix all Kähler and complex structure moduli.
Both the AdS minimum and its de Sitter uplift fix all Kähler and complex structure moduli.
de Sitter uplift is applied to the AdS minimum, lifting it to a metastable state.
Both the AdS minimum and its de Sitter uplift are tachyon-free, ensuring vacuum stability.
Both the AdS minimum and its de Sitter uplift are tachyon-free.
Fixing all moduli has been difficult to achieve in the KKLT scenario; this work provides an alternative approach.
For vacua described in this paper, the gravitino mass is independent of the flux discretuum, indicating decoupling.
The ratio of the string scale to the 4d Planck scale is hierarchically small but flux dependent.
The string scale to Planck scale ratio is hierarchically small but flux dependent.
The inclusion of alpha' corrections plays a crucial role in the structure of the potential.
Alpha' corrections are essential for understanding the large volume regime structure.
The paper studies Calabi-Yau flux compactifications to achieve moduli stabilisation in the large volume limit.
F-theory compactifications are defined via elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau manifolds used to compactify extra dimensions.
F-theory is formulated via an elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau fourfold as the fundamental geometric object.
Elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau fourfolds are the geometric basis of F-theory compactifications.
F-theory string compactifications can realize the exact chiral spectrum of the Standard Model.
F-theory compactifications realize gauge coupling unification in the context of the Standard Model.
All global consistency conditions must be satisfied for F-theory to yield valid compactifications.
Global consistency conditions reduce to a single criterion on the base of the elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau fourfold.
Toric bases define the base geometry of elliptically fibered Calabi-Yau fourfolds in F-theory.
For toric bases, global consistency criterion depends only on an associated polytope.
Algebraic geometry is utilized to reduce all global consistency conditions to a single criterion.
Toric bases are defined combinatorially via associated polytopes.
Random fields represented as integrals with respect to infinitely divisible measures are shown to be infinitely divisible.
The integral representation uses an infinitely divisible random measure as the integrator.
Integral representation is composed of integrals of deterministic functions with respect to random measures.
Infinite divisibility is defined via decomposition of the probability distribution into convolution powers.
A random field is infinitely divisible if its distribution is an n-th convolution power for all positive integers n.
Infinite divisibility of random measures is defined through the infinite divisibility of the characteristic functional.
Infinitely divisible random fields are a special class of random fields satisfying the infinite divisibility property.
Four dimensional reflexive polyhedra encode the data for smooth Calabi-Yau threefolds that are hypersurfaces in toric varieties.
Calabi-Yau threefolds are hypersurfaces in toric varieties.
30,108 distinct pairs of Hodge numbers of the resulting Calabi-Yau manifolds are obtained from the 473,800,776 reflexive polyhedra.
All these spaces and hence the corresponding string vacua are connected via a chain of singular transitions.
Reflexive polyhedra have important applications in perturbative string theory.
Reflexive polyhedra have important applications in non-perturbative string theory.
All these spaces are connected via a chain of singular transitions.
Calabi-Yau threefolds are hypersurfaces in toric varieties defined by reflexive polyhedra.
Reflexive polyhedra are four-dimensional lattice polytopes.
Reflexive polyhedra are lattice polytopes whose polar duals are also lattice polytopes.
The refined version of this conjecture says that this range is of the order of the naturally built in scale, namely the Planck scale.
The Swampland Distance Conjecture claims that effective theories derived from a consistent theory of quantum gravity only have a finite range of validity.
Effective theories derived from a consistent theory of quantum gravity have finite range of validity.
The refined version says that this range is of the order of the Planck scale.
Calabi-Yau compactification is a string theory mechanism for deriving four-dimensional physics.
Extra spatial dimensions are compactified on Calabi-Yau manifolds to obtain four-dimensional physics.
Moduli spaces of Calabi-Yau compactification include Kähler moduli spaces controlling deformations.
Field distances arise in the moduli spaces of Calabi-Yau compactification.
The investigation focuses on non-geometric phases of Kähler moduli spaces of Calabi-Yau compactifications.
It is investigated whether the Refined Swampland Distance Conjecture is consistent with proper field distances arising in moduli spaces.
Field distances in non-geometric phases were found to be smaller than the Planck-length.
The conjecture will imply drastic consequences for string theory model building.
Calabi-Yau compactifications are used as a foundation for string theory model building.
Our starting point is highly warped IIB compactifications with nontrivial NS and RR three-form fluxes.
NS and RR three-form fluxes contribute to fixing moduli in IIB compactifications.
Known corrections to the superpotential from Euclidean D-brane instantons fix moduli.
Known corrections to the superpotential from gaugino condensation fix moduli.
Corrections to the superpotential lead to models with all moduli fixed.
All moduli fixed models yield a supersymmetric AdS vacuum.
Inclusion of anti-D3 branes in warped geometry allows uplift of AdS minimum to metastable de Sitter ground state.
Anti-D3 branes uplift AdS minima derived from moduli-stabilized IIB theory to dS vacua.
Anti-D3 branes are incorporated in the resulting warped geometry to uplift the AdS minimum.
The construction yields metastable de Sitter vacua with lifetimes much greater than 10^10 years.
Proven that the lifetime of dS space in string theory is always shorter than the recurrence time.
